id_table_1.caption: indicates capability,indicates limitation, and “” hints at the potential for easy extension. We cover a range of tasks including text conversation (Text-Con), image comprehension (Img-Com), image generation (Img-Gen), image editing (Img-Edit), video generation (Vid-Gen), audio generation (Aud-Gen), image segmentation (Img-Seg), and image detection (Img-Det).
table: MLLMs Text-Con Img-Com Img-Gen Img-Edit Vid-Gen Aud-Gen Img-Seg Img-Det LLaMA (Touvron et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ Vicuna (Chiang et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ Flaminggo (Alayrac et al., 2022 ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ BLIP2 (Li et al., 2023b ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ mPLUG-Owl (Ye et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ DetGPT (Pi et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✔ LLaVA (Liu et al., 2023c ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ Mini-GPT4 (Zhu et al., 2023b ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ Audiogpt (Huang et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✔ ✗ ✗ Otter (Li et al., 2023a ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ LISA (Lai et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✔ ✗ GLaMM (Rasheed et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✗ ✔ ✗ NExTGPT (Wu et al., 2023 ) ✔ ✔ ✔ ✗ ✔ ✔ ✗ ✗ LLMBind (Ours) ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ -
references: Recently, the emergence of Large Language Models (LLM) has ushered AI into a new era. With the open-sourcing of LLM models like LLaMA           (Touvron et al.,             2023            )          and Vicuna           (Chiang et al.,             2023            )          , numerous research works have successfully explored methods to extend LLMs to other modalities, including video, audio, and images. This has led to the development of a variety of related MLLM models, as shown in                  Table                   1                . For instance, Flamingo           (Alayrac et al.,             2022            )          employs cross-attention structures for visual-text interaction, while DetGPT           (Pi et al.,             2023            )          connects multimodal LLMs with detectors, enabling object detection based on user instructions. BLIP-2           (Li et al.,             2023b            )          encodes input images into queries using the Q-Former structure. mPLUG-Owl           (Ye et al.,             2023            )          and LLaVA           (Liu et al.,             2023c            )          encode images into image features using image encoders, which are then combined with text embeddings for LLM learning. LISA           (Lai et al.,             2023            )          achieves referring segmentation by training LLMs to output mask token embeddings in an end-to-end manner. NExTGPT           (Wu et al.,             2023            )          implements multimodal generation by aligning the output of the adapter, which is added after the LLM, with the output text features from the text encoder of various generation models           (Liu et al.,             2023b            ; Rombach et al.,             2022a            )          .

table: Method FD ( ↓ ↓ \downarrow ) IS ( ↑ ↑ \uparrow ) DiffSound (Yang et al., 2023a ) 47.68 4.01 AudioLDM-S (Liu et al., 2023b ) 29.48 6.90 AudioLDM-L (Liu et al., 2023b ) 23.31 8.13 NExT-GPT (Wu et al., 2023 ) 23.58 8.35 LLMBind (ours) 22.90 8.77
references: Video & Audio & Image Generation.          In the text-to-audio generation task, as shown in                  Table                   5                , LLMBind adopts CoDi           (Tang et al.,             2023            )          as the baseline generation model and achieves an FD score of 22.90 and an IS score of 8.77 on the AudioCaps           (Kim et al.,             2019            )          dataset, outperforming models like NeXT-GPT and AudioLDM. In the text-to-image generation task, as shown in                  Table                   5                , LLMBind employs Stable Diffusion           (Rombach et al.,             2022a            )          as the baseline generation model and attains an FID score of 11.21 on the COCO-caption           (Lin et al.,             2014            )          dataset, surpassing models like NeXT-GPT and CoDi. In the text-to-video generation task, as depicted in                  Table                   5                , LLMBind selects ModelScopeT2V           (Wang et al.,             2023            )          as the baseline generation model and obtains an FID of 11.09 and a CLIPSIM score of 0.2930 on the MSR-VTT           (Xu et al.,             2016            )          dataset, with a higher FID score and a slightly lower CLIPSIM score than NExT-GPT.In terms of generation tasks, since LLMBind does not perform lossy training on the generation models, it can be assumed that its generative capability largely depends on the chosen generation models. With sufficient computational resources, LLMBind can employ better-performing models to achieve superior generation results selectively.

id_table_4.caption: among LLMBind (ours) and previous related works. The phrase “1.5x7B” means that half of the layers in the 7B model are MoE layers.
table: Method gIoU cIoU OVSeg ( Liang et al. , 2023 ) 28.5 18.6 GRES ( Liu et al. , 2023a ) 22.4 19.9 X-Decoder ( Zou et al. , 2023a ) 22.6 17.9 SEEM ( Zou et al. , 2023b ) 25.5 21.2 LISA-7B ( Lai et al. , 2023 ) 52.9 54.0 LISA-Llama2-13B ( Lai et al. , 2023 ) 60.0 67.8 LISA-13B ( Lai et al. , 2023 ) 56.2 62.9 LLMBind-1.5x7B (ours) 62.4 66.9
references: Referring Segmentation.          For referring segmentation task, as illustrated in                  Table                   6                , LLMBind achieves superior results on various datasets. On the refCOCO dataset, for the val, testA, and testB splits, LLMBind achieves scores of 76.9, 78.5, and 73.2, respectively. Similarly, on the refCOCO dataset, the model records scores of 67.8, 71.9, and 60.8 for val, testA, and testB. On the refCOCOG dataset, LLMBind achieves 69.8 and 70.8.

Reasoning Segmentation.          We evaluate the performance of LLMBind on the referring segmentation task. For a fair comparison, we use the LISA-7B model as our benchmark. As shown in                  Table                   6                , LLMBind achieves GIoU and CIoU scores of 62.4 and 66.9 on the ReasonSeg dataset           (Lai et al.,             2023            )          , which exceeds LISA-7B with a large margin (8.8 and 12.9) and comparable with LISA-13B.

table: LoRA Training MoE Expert Top-K gIoU cIoU RANK Steps Layers Nums Experts 4 7k 16/32 4 2 59.4 62.5 8 7k 16/32 4 2 58.9 65.8 12 7k 16/32 4 2 58.7 66.2 16 7k 16/32 4 2 58.6 65.2
references: Rank of LoRA.          As shown in                  Table                   9                , we conduct detailed experiments with different ranks of LoRA and found that our framework exhibits slight performance variation across various settings. Therefore, we chose a final rank of 8, for a balance between training cost and model performance.

Training Steps.          Regarding the number of training iterations, we design experiments with four distinct settings: 5k, 6k, 7k, and 8k training steps. These variations were chosen to systematically evaluate the impact of training duration on model performance. As detailed in                  Table                   9                , our findings reveal a clear trend: longer iteration steps consistently yield improvements in both gIoU and cIoU metrics.

Number of MoE Layers.          For the configuration of MoE layers, we conduct experiments with 16, 10, 8, and 0 layers, with the results presented in                  Table                   9                . The model’s performance generally improves with an increasing number of MoE layers. Due to limited model memory, we do not perform experiments with 32 MoE layers, but we believe that more MoE layers could further enhance the performance.

table: LoRA Training MoE Expert Top-K gIoU cIoU RANK Steps Layers Nums Experts 8 7k 16/32 4 2 59.4 66.5 8 7k 16/32 3 2 58.9 65.8 8 7k 16/32 2 2 58.7 66.2 8 7k 16/32 2 1 58.6 65.2
references: Number of All Experts and Top-K Activated Experts.          In our MoE framework, the number of all experts and the number of Top-K activated experts are both crucial. In                  Table                   10                , we briefly explore how different numbers of experts and activated experts affect model performance. The findings align with our expectations: when the number of experts is fixed, more activated experts improve model performance; similarly, increasing the number of experts enhances performance when the number of activated experts is constant.
